intro: Peucedanum parishii, commonly known as the Tibetan cowparsley, is a herbaceous perennial plant native to the high-altitude regions of the Tibetan Plateau. It belongs to the Apiaceae family, characterized by its umbellate inflorescences and aromatic foliage. The plant typically grows to a height of 30–60 cm, with slender stems and finely divided, fern-like leaves. Its small white or pale yellow flowers appear in clusters, and it is adapted to cold, arid environments. Peucedanum parishii is of interest to botanists and horticulturists due to its unique ecological niche and potential medicinal properties.
